Elliotte Harold wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
>  > Also, they tend to constrain me to the idea that each method should have
>  > separate tests, and that makes future refactorings more annoying: it
>  > couples too many tests to the implementation details of a class.
> 
> Do they [post-generated test skeletons] do this by writing test for the private and package (default)
> access parts of the class? If so I'd agree that's brain-damaged. You
> should be able to change these parts of the class.

No; rather they do it by assuming that all methods might be invoked by 
brain-dead clients who haphazardly pass invalid data around to each 
other. In APIs I publish in class libraries, I worry about that; but in 
code used by other code my team writes, I am less worried. As I often 
say -- which I steal from others -- if I pass me null, the invoker is 
probably broken, and not the invoked.
> 
> However, if the problem id that they're tying you too much to the public
> parts of a class, then I suspect that's an indication that too much of
> the class is public.

Indeed... I prefer to use interface/implementation separation over 
public/private separation. Funny thing: the more interface-rich my 
designs are, the less concern there is over too much of a class being 
public, because collaborators rely on each other mostly through 
narrowing interfaces.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
